data.title: Constellium SE: Why This Stock Is My Top Pick For 2026
data.description:
Introduction

In this article, I aim to scour the landscape of publicly traded equities to find the number one choice for 2026. Ultimately, I conclude that the choice is Constellium SE (CSTM) for three main reasons: first, it strongly benefits from numerous secular tailwinds (so many nascent industries will depend on aluminum and aluminum alloys); second, the company is shifting toward a higher-margin mix of products; and third, the stock currently trades with an extremely attractive valuation. I argue that the market views this stock as a cyclical processor of aluminum, when in fact it is growing into a major supplier of high-margin parts for automotive and aerospace customers.

Methodology

Creating the Shortlist

I want to start by imagining what the best stock to buy right now would look like. First, we're in a time in which the impacts of AI are uncertain. There are two competing themes: that we're at the start of a transformational AI revolution or that we're nearing the peak of an AI bubble in which revenues at companies like Nvidia, Microsoft, and OpenAI are actually illusory. The best stock for 2026 has to be a winner in both outcomes. I don't want my pick to lean too heavily on getting the AI macro thesis correct.

Second, I want a company that has a large barrier to entry - in other words, a wide moat. A moat is difficult to quantify, but generally strong profitability metrics (high margins relative to the industry and sector) are indicative of a company with a sustainable competitive advantage. If the company is in a monopolistic or oligarchic market, then that would be ideal.

Third, I want a company that has a simple, easy-to-understand business model. I want a pick where every reader can easily understand how the company makes money.

Finally, I want a company that is at least fairly valued. I use both Seeking Alpha's valuation grade and the PEG ratio (which is one of my preferred valuation metrics) to help narrow down the list, looking for stocks with the following characteristics:

  • Quant Rating = Strong Buy
  • Valuation Grade = C or better
  • PEG Ratio < 1.2

This screening produced 48 names, which I narrowed down to the following shortlist: MU, AMD, BNS, BCS, DELL, GM, CLS, and BRK.B, CSTM. I added some other "Strong Buy" stocks into consideration myself: AVGO, LITE, NESR, NEM, and IBRK.

Trimming the Field

Some of these names are too integrated into the danger of an AI CapEx Bubble for my liking: MU, AMD, AVGO, DELL, LITE, and CLS. So I discarded those first. I also don't want potential low-margin value traps and/or financial institutions, so that eliminates BCS, BNS, and GM from the list. NESR I eliminated from consideration because I believe it's too tied up with Middle Eastern geopolitical risk. Finally, I didn't want companies whose futures are tied directly to gold, as I believe it's become a bit of a speculative market (for example, kids in China buying up "gold beads"). So that eliminated NEM from consideration.

That leaves three finalists: IBKR, BRK.B and CSTM. Let's go through each one.

I had originally intended to write this article on IBRK. I thought it was a perfect stock to pitch to the Seeking Alpha audience for obvious reasons. But when I got to valuing the company, I used a residual income approach, and I just couldn't justify the current valuation even with optimistic assumptions. Even though I think it's a great business (and my favorite online broker), valuation is non-negotiable, so I cannot recommend the stock as the best pick of 2026 if the valuation leaves little upside potential. It is a stock I will buy if I can get it at a cheaper price, though.

Berkshire Hathaway is a company I think is legitimately undervalued right now. Berkshire has about $358 billion cash on hand and a $290 billion public equity portfolio. So with a market cap of $1.09 trillion, the remaining part of the business, which is a cash-generating machine, is valued at $442 billion at the time of writing. That's about a 9.8x multiple on the segment's operating earnings. So in my view, BRK.B (or BRK.A) is a great buy for 2026, given that it's insulated from either AI disruption or an AI bubble and tends to do well in choppy markets and during corrections. However, if there is anything that doesn't scream "hidden gem" it's Berkshire Hathaway. Anyone can tell you to buy Berkshire, but it's not an idea that's worthy of a "2026 top pick."

So by process of elimination, we land on the real top pick of 2026 in my view: Constellium SE. This stock immediately caught my eye. First, it has one of the highest Quant ratings on Seeking Alpha at 4.95 (ranked 31 out of 4281), and the metrics for this stock are flashing green across the board:

Valuation looks extremely attractive on almost all metrics:

The company also has strong profitability metrics. Return on equity is 32.93%, compared to a sector median of 5.44%. It is, however, a relatively low-margin business (more on that later). The company is projected to grow EPS at nearly 70% CAGR over the next 3-5 years.

On its face, this stock almost looks too good to be true, which has me asking, "What's the catch?" Although ratings and numbers can flag potentially good ideas, the devil is in the details of the company's fundamentals.

Business Model: How Does CSTM Make Money?

Quoting the company's most recent 10K:

We are a global leader in the development, manufacture and sale of a broad range of high value-added specialty rolled and extruded aluminum products to the aerospace, space, defense, packaging, automotive, commercial transportation and general industrial end-markets. Our business model is to add value by converting aluminum into semi-fabricated and in some instances fully-fabricated alloyed aluminum products which meet stringent and performance-critical requirements from our customers. Our product portfolio generally commands higher margins as compared to less differentiated, more commoditized aluminum products. Our business model aims to pass through aluminum price exposure by pricing our products to include the cost of the metal purchased and hedging any remaining exposure to achieve aluminum price neutrality.

One important thing to note is that this stock is not a speculative play on the price of aluminum. In fact, the company hedges its exposure to aluminum prices, which means that the success of the business is tied to the amount of refined aluminum products that are demanded rather than how aluminum is trading in spot markets.

The company has three operating segments: Aerospace & Transportation (A&T), Packaging and Automotive Rolled Products (P&ARP), and Automotive Structures & Industry (AS&I). The A&T segment provides technical products to companies in the aerospace, space, and industrial sectors (companies like Airbus, Blue Origin, SpaceX, and others). P&ARP is the biggest segment by revenue, but it's also the lowest margin. It essentially provides rolled aluminum for products like beverage cans and auto body sheets. AS&I provides technical products for automobiles like crash management systems and body structures.

CSTM is essentially a middleman between raw aluminum (both primary and recycled) and producers of goods that require aluminum. The following graphics from the company's 10-K show Constellium's position in the aluminum supply chain:

Why is CSTM a Good Buy Now?

There are a number of tailwinds I see for this company. I'll go through them one by one:

1. Recyclability of Aluminum

Since aluminum is infinitely recyclable, the more that is mined and refined, the larger the recyclable pool is. Since recyclable aluminum is cheaper than primary aluminum, CSTM's input prices are likely to decrease over time as it uses more and more recycled aluminum as its primary input. CSTM actually recycles aluminum themselves. One location at Muscle Shoals called "Element 13" is one of the largest recycling facilities on the planet, with the capacity to recycle 20 billion used cans per year. The company has the capacity to recycle 750,000 metric tons of aluminum per year. Recycling aluminum is a massive cost saver vs smelting primary aluminum from raw bauxite - it's about 95% less energy intensive, and the raw material cost is lower. Constellium has contracts with its customers to purchase recyclable scrap, so the company's sold products can become their own raw materials. Going back to the above graphic, with suppliers on the left and customers on the right, we could almost turn this into a loop. In some cases Constellium's customers are its suppliers - it buys aluminum scrap from its customers and recycles it into new raw materials.

CSTM still depends on primary aluminum for 60% of its raw material supply. But the company has been expanding recycling operations, which has the potential to expand profit margins by lowering raw material costs.

2. Automotive Transition to EVs/Greater Fuel Efficiency

High-quality aluminum products are key to the EV transition. Because EV batteries are so heavy, "lightweighting" the rest of the vehicle is key to attractive range. Aluminum tends to be the best product for that, given its high strength-to-weight ratio. Of course, makers of traditional automobiles also want to achieve the greatest efficiency they can, which necessitates greater reliance on aluminum as well. CSTM is one of the largest providers of aluminum products to major car manufacturers in North America and Europe. CSTM stands ready to benefit from the major push toward efficiency in both EV and ICE vehicles.

3. Constellium is a Key Supplier in the New Space Race

Blue Origin's New Glenn, SpaceX's Falcon 9, Space Launch System, and the Orion Spacecraft are all users of CSTM's aluminum alloy called "Airware," which is a line of proprietary aluminum-lithium alloys. This kind of alloy is frequently used in rockets, especially reusable rockets like Falcon 9, because of its high strength-to-weight ratio. While Starship is unique in using fully stainless-steel alloys, nearly every other launch vehicle (like Blue Origin's New Glenn) uses aluminum-lithium alloys. If you believe that space is about to become commercialized, then CSTM could be an indirect way to invest in that future. The fact that CSTM, a European-headquartered company, actively won contracts with SpaceX, Blue Origin, and NASA away from American legacy aluminum-lithium suppliers is strong evidence of the quality of the company's product for spaceflight specifically.

4. Record Backlog in Commercial Aircraft

Constellium is a major supplier to manufacturers of commercial aircraft, particularly Airbus. There is currently a massive backlog of 17,000 aircraft (60% of the active fleet), which amounts to 12 years of production at current capacities. Airbus alone has a backlog of 8754 aircraft as of the end of 2025. Since Constellium is one of the major suppliers to the commercial aerospace industry, this huge backlog guarantees many years of demand and significant growth potential for the company's A&T products.

5. New Market Opportunities

Finally, I wouldn't bet against the company opening up new markets for its products. In the most recent earnings call, CEO Ingrid Joerg said

We also believe there are some opportunities in land-based defense and semiconductor markets given current market dynamics. In most industrial markets, we are focused on niche high value-added applications.

Niche, high value-added applications are where the stronger margins lie. Aluminum and aluminum alloys are in high demand in multiple disruptive industries, like EVs, data centers, green energy, drones, robotics, and more. So this company is poised to expand its product lines to high-growth industries where it can command higher profit margins, in my view.

Major Risks

1. Energy Prices

CSTM uses an enormous amount of energy for its operations, primarily natural gas and electricity. A rise in these input costs could diminish gross profit margins. The company purchases energy through forward fixed commitments and long-term contracts, which reduces price uncertainty somewhat. However, it would not be immune to an energy price shock. The risk from energy prices could be amplified by the fact that CSTM supplies automotive and aerospace companies. Higher energy prices could reduce demand for air travel and automobiles, which in turn could lead to CSTM's customers placing fewer orders. That risk, however, is tempered by the fact that higher fuel prices would increase demand for lightweight materials, which could be a tailwind to CSTM.

While I was writing this article, the US and Israel carried out an attack on Iran. If this attack causes an energy price shock, it could be a significant financial burden to the company. As I mentioned, the company is resilient to short-term energy shocks because it locks in so much of its future energy costs in futures and long-term contracts with suppliers. As I mentioned in the Opportunities section, CSTM also uses recycling to derive much of its raw aluminum, which further shields the company from energy price volatility since recycling is so much less energy intensive. Because recycling uses 95% less energy than primary smelting, CSTM has a clear advantage over its competitors in the event of a drawn-out energy price shock, even though it could hurt profitability eventually.

Finally, CSTM has shown the ability to pass higher input costs on to customers, which it could potentially do with energy prices as well.

2. Middleman Risk

When you're a middleman in a supply chain, you face risks from both ends. If CSTM's customers experience a drop in demand, the demand for aluminum products could decrease. However, I think that is unlikely. Aluminum used in consumer staples is likely to experience robust demand, since consumer staples is typically a non-cyclical industry. Aerospace is more cyclical, but the massive backlog for commercial aircraft suggests that demand is unlikely to evaporate any time soon.

On the other end, CSTM faces supply-side risk. A geopolitical crisis that shocks aluminum supply could pose a major risk, although the company has proven resilient to President Trump's high tariffs on aluminum. In fact, tariffs have actually benefitted the company tremendously since the aluminum it gets from domestic scrap is tariff-free, but the tariffs push up the price of refined aluminum. So tariffs allow the company to capture a larger spread between the cost of scrap and the selling price.

If, however, there was a major supply shock with primary aluminum, that could drive up the price of aluminum scrap metal, which would hurt CSTM on the supply side. The company would burn through cash in a potential supply shock. The vast majority of the world's bauxite mining is done in Australia, China, Brazil, India, and Guinea, while very little mining is done domestically. There is not yet enough recyclable aluminum in circulation to meet demand, which means that continued extraction of bauxite (which gets refined into alumina, then smelted into aluminum) in those countries is vital.

3. High Debt

The company does have a worrying amount of debt. Total debt is about $2.06 billion on a market cap of $3.36 billion at the time of writing. Net interest expense was $99 million, only about 8.2% of gross profit and 1.2% of revenues for 2025. The company issued bonds in 2024 that mature in 2032: â‚¬300 million of euro-denominated senior unsecured notes bearing interest of 5.375% and $350 million of U.S. dollar-denominated senior unsecured notes due 2032 bearing interest of 6.375%. All the company's bonds are trading at a premium to par value, meaning the bond market is rating the bonds as lower risk than when they were issued. The company does face refinancing risk when the bonds mature. $325 million worth of notes mature in June 2028, while the rest mature in 2029 and 2032. I believe the company's strong cash flows recently provide an opportunity to decrease leverage, which would further expand margins.

The company's balance sheet has significantly strengthened in the past few years, which is another sign that it can manage its debt and that it's on a long trend toward improved solvency. The growth in book value of equity (representing total assets minus total liabilities) over the last few years is evidence of the improving balance sheet: total book value of equity has gone from -600 million in 2016 to -140 million in 2020 to 952 million in the most recent report.

So are these risks big enough that they turn our hidden gem into a chunk of coal? I don't believe so. It would be impossible to find any stock with all opportunities and no risks - in other words, a hidden gem with no rough edges. I believe the opportunities I laid out above significantly outweigh the risks.

Stock Performance

CSTM's stock has been on a roller coaster ride since its IPO in May 2013:

The stock recently broke out above a longer than 10-year trading range, between about $4 and $22 per share, which I view as a bullish move. In the last year the stock is up nearly 120%, which raises concerns that it could be overbought. But I think the strong valuation metrics counter that concern. One year ago, CSTM had a B+ valuation grade on Seeking Alpha's Quantitative Scorecard, while today it earns an A+ valuation score. If anything, that suggests that the stock price hasn't quite caught up with the improved fundamentals. The relative strength index at ~56 doesn't suggest that the stock is currently overbought either:

Moat/Competitive Advantage

Each segment of Constellium's business has significant competitive advantages. One moat comes from its Airware alloys (for the A&T segment). Creating these special alloys requires billions in capital expenditures and decades of R&D. The market is solidly oligopolistic, with only a few major competitors: Howmet Aerospace and Arconic primarily. But this competition (albeit limited) is a positive. Demand is so great that no single company can fill it. The entire pie is growing so fast that any company with 20-30% market share (which Constellium has) is going to see tremendous growth.

The automotive segment has a large moat because Constellium co-engineers with automakers, making the switching costs high. If an automaker crash tests its vehicles using Constellium's products, then switching the design to use another company's products instead is extremely expensive. It would require an entire redesign and recertification of the vehicle. This is not just generic metal that Constellium is selling to automakers: it takes years of collaborative custom designing to develop these products for companies like BMW and Ford. That said, automakers are extremely cost-sensitive, so although Constellium has a moat in this segment, I believe the aerospace moat is stronger.

Another moat for the company is in the more boring P&ARP segment. The moat here is volume and capital scale. Manufacturing rolled aluminum for beverage cans is actually much harder than it sounds. It requires flawless metallurgy to ensure that the thin alloys that make up beverage cans can withstand the pressure once they're filled. The monetary barriers to entry in this space are astronomically high. However, CSTM doesn't have the strongest pricing power in this segment, which is evidenced by the extremely low margins relative to the other segments. So although it would be difficult for newcomers to compete, buyers still have strong pricing power.

Overall, I rate CSTM's moat as wide, particularly due to the aerospace segment. The other segments contribute meaningfully, but the proprietary alloys used in aerospace are what give the company its strongest competitive advantage, in my view.

Valuation

I use an EV/EBITDA model to value CSTM. My thesis is that the market is rating CSTM more as a commodity aluminum supplier and not based on the strong moat it has developed through the proprietary Airware aluminum-lithium alloys that are fueling the company's growth in high-margin segments. The forward EV/EBITDA ratio for the company is 6.48 compared to a 9.00 average in the Materials sector. I believe that CSTM should command a multiple higher than the Materials sector average, but to be conservative, I use a value of 9.0 forward EV/EBITDA to value the company.

The company is targeting $780-$820 million adjusted EBITDA in 2026. I used the midpoint of that range ($800 million) and a 9.0 multiple to get a fair enterprise value of $7.2 billion. Subtracting net debt of 1.94 billion gets a fair equity value of $5.26 billion. Then dividing by the number of diluted shares of 142 million gives us a fair value per share of about $37, which is an upside of about 48% over the current share price.

Final Thoughts

CSTM is my top pick for 2026 because I see a number of tailwinds for the stock, but I want to emphasize that I'm not necessarily recommending it as a long-term "buy and hold" pick. This is an industry in which fortunes can change rapidly, and so the validity of my thesis needs to be continually reevaluated. At the moment, I believe the stars are in alignment for this particular company and that we may have identified a diamond in the rough.

Editor's Note: This article was submitted as part of Seeking Alpha's Top 2026 Long Idea investment competition, which runs through February 28. With cash prizes, this competition -- open to all analysts -- is one you don't want to miss. If you are interested in becoming an analyst and taking part in the competition, click here to find out more and submit your article today!

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: If This Is A 2022 Market Repeat, Here Is What Likely Happens Next
data.description:
Introduction

The goal of forecasting is not to predict the future, but to tell you what you need to know to take meaningful action in the present" ~ Paul Saffo

Timing matters, and it matters greatly. I have spent the last 35 years trading, researching, and constructing algorithms to identify and leverage the value across fundamental, technical, and behavioral finance models. Of the ten portfolio models designed for optimal portfolio mixes for members to beat the market at Value & Momentum Breakouts, eight come from enhancing well-tested anomaly research in published financial journals. All of the models continue to outperform the S&P 500 in live forward testing here on Seeking Alpha, and again this year.

If This is a 2022 Market Repeat, Here is What Happens Next

First, let me be clear that I am not under any illusion that 2026 is identical to 2022, nor that making comparisons of two completely different time periods is not without a myriad of flaws. This article is intended to capture and share a large number of significant similarities and show you what we are doing to beat the markets again this year in our 9th year on Seeking Alpha.

As I write this article, the US and Israel are launching air strikes against Iran over the weekend, and I have no idea what future events may unfold from this last day of February. I am reminded that back in February of 2022, the world was shocked by the Russian invasion of Ukraine that continues as a terrible conflict today, more than four years later.

The structure of this article will begin with a broad macro perspective that progresses to more sector details and shorter time frames. Within each section I will share some of the models, signals, and portfolios we are using to beat the markets again this year. Any one of these following sections could be an article by itself with much more detail than we discuss daily in our community. Instead, I will let the charts do most of the talking as succinctly as possible.

The Macro Perspective

From the macro perspective, I begin with a look at the S&P 500 from 2020 through this past week. Overlayed on the S&P 500 chart are two Fibonacci retracement models comparing past and present similarities with future price supports.

This technical price model suggests that market moves follow the Fibonacci sequence, and in downturns, look for supports at the levels indicated. In 2022, the S&P 500 declines followed the retracement to -50% declines around the 3,500 support level, but not before testing the -23.6% level first at 4,200. If such a repeat were to occur in 2026, we would expect the first retracement to the 6,500 support levels as illustrated in the chart.

As I have shared in prior market forecast articles about a strong market rotation, there are also other strong macro similarities forming back to 2022.

  • New Fed Chair, QE & Lower Rates: Where The 2026 Piotroski-Graham Value Stocks Are Hiding

The following S&P 500 Growth vs. Value chart from 1994 not only shows the extreme divergence between the two investing approaches but also some similarities forming from 2022.

So How Are We Trading This Macro Perspective?

Our long-term portfolios are based on a variety of fundamental and forensic algorithms published in peer-reviewed research that have been well documented over many years to provide positive market alpha over 2-year periods. This year we have also restarted the anomaly portfolio, where evidence strongly suggests CFO insiders provide outsized returns within certain purchase amounts of their own companies.

From the charts, we anticipate that the Piotroski-Graham value portfolios and our Dividend approach leveraging multiple long-term models may begin to outperform the record gains in the pure growth market segments like technology.

Additionally, I share a few bonus selections, leading several of our long-term portfolios for members. These portfolios are also updated mid-year and at the end of the year. (STKL) SunOpta has recently agreed to a deal that will take the company private at around $6.50/share. 12 stocks in the CFO Insider portfolio are delivering better than 10% returns, while only 5 have larger than -10% returns in the early months of this long-term analysis.

In our unique dividend portfolio (VZ), Verizon continues in strong positive momentum conditions, +23.1% YTD, with a recent earnings beat and a high 5.61% dividend. Supporting the dividend rotation model is the fact that 7 of 10 selections are up over 12.7% YTD, with fully half the portfolio producing over 20% returns, not including large dividends. It will be interesting to see how the similarities to 2022 could fuel larger gains in value and dividend stocks this year.

Lastly, the Joseph Piotroski and Benjamin Graham model, leveraging two value algorithms from across many decades of time, has produced consistently strong returns in 9 years of live forward testing here on SA without a negative return. Leading this portfolio to date is a strong energy stock (NBR), Nabors Industries LTD, up 46.57% YTD.

The S&P 500 weekly momentum gauge chart from my proprietary doctoral study algorithm is shown below. We continue in a negative weekly signal the past 5 weeks that has seen the S&P 500 decline -0.87% and the Nasdaq down -2.32% in the worst monthly performance since March of last year.

The Sector Perspective

Looking back at 2022 and examining the strongest returns from our Growth & Dividend portfolio, it was clear that the energy sector was responsible for virtually anything positive that year. The Mega Cap sectors of technology, consumer cyclicals, and communications weighed down the market indices for large declines that we will examine in the next section.

As you can see, the higher dividend sectors of utilities and defensive stocks outperformed, and basic materials remained solid as a hedge against large market declines.

While no one knows the final outcome for sector returns in 2026, we do know that if similarities to 2022 continue, we could see the same rotation that we experienced this past February:

Two Sectors to Consider Closely

While we trade and monitor all the market sectors on our momentum gauges, the Technology and Financial sector are of particular importance. Both sectors are delivering large gains in our Active ETF portfolio bear funds YTD, with similarities again to 2022.

Back in 2022, the financial sector gauges were overwhelmingly negative for most of the year. Banks and related services in this sector often reflect the health of the markets and, in some cases, give us early warnings of liquidity problems and broader market risks. On the monthly sector gauge below, you can see that the signal applied to the yellow (FAS) Direxion Daily Financial Bull 3x Shares turned negative from near the November 2021 highs at $140/share. The monthly signal did not turn positive again for nine months until August, at around $80/share, representing about a -42% decline.

2022 Monthly Financial Gauges

2026 Weekly Financial Gauges

While it is far too soon to say the financial sector looks like 2022, we are already seeing some cracks in private credit markets.

  • Private credit default risk in software could top 15%, warns Marathonâ€™s Bruce Richards: BBG interview

The sharply rising negative momentum in this sector approaching levels that we have not seen since the worst market downturns last year has kept us in bear funds like (FAZ) Direxion Daily Financial Bear 3x Shares from January for gains of +13.28% on the weekly ETF signal.

Technology is the second sector we will consider closely and also the largest sector on the major indices like the S&P 500 (SPY) and Nasdaq (QQQ) funds. I never know how long the negative signal will last, but we saw large drawdowns both in 2022 and 2024.

The (SOXL) Direxion Daily Semiconductor Bull 3X Shares fund, the main takeaways are two-fold:

1. SOXL represents the largest stocks in the market and in the technology sector, with NVIDIA (NVDA), Micron (MU), Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), and Broadcom (AVGO) reporting earnings on Wednesday. The direction of this fund greatly determines the direction of technology and the broader major averages.

In fact, the current multiple discriminant analysis chart of Broadcom is in maximum negative segment 2 conditions ahead of key earnings next week. Just as NVIDIA is also turning to maximum negative conditions following a record earnings beat last week.

2. We are now seeing the 3rd test of around $70/share in the SOXL fund that represented major market peaks in 2022 and over -62% declines, which I also detailed back in 2024. On my heavily notation-filled chart of this fund, you can see how prior breakdowns unfolded with large bear bounces along the way to new lows.

The last comparison to the technology sector is the Bitcoin chart (BTC/USD). For months I have been tracking and sharing the remarkable bitcoin similarities to the prior bimodal topping pattern of 2022. We are even seeing extreme detail in the RSI indicator declining toward record levels to form another potential base for long-term recovery.

Again, look for these remarkable similarities to find a bottom and another good opportunity to more aggressively risk your capital.

FINRA cautions investors that:

Exchange-traded funds (ETFs) that offer leverage or that are designed to perform inversely to the index or benchmark they track, or both, are growing in number and popularity. While such products may be useful in some sophisticated trading strategies, they are highly complex financial instruments that are typically designed to achieve their stated objectives on a daily basis. Due to the effects of compounding, their performance over longer periods of time can differ significantly from their stated daily objective. Therefore, inverse and leveraged ETFs that are reset daily typically are unsuitable for retail investors who plan to hold them for longer than one trading session, particularly in volatile markets.

The Mega Cap Perspective

The Magnificent 7 or Mega Cap 8 analysis has been detailed previously in my other recent articles like this one:

  • Mega Cap 8 Declining As Top Performers Emerge In Major Value Rotation

I will not go into as much detail here except to highlight the potential for pullback similar to 2022 with large bear bounces and extremely high volatility that we have not seen yet.

The critical difference so far into 2026 is that we have not seen anywhere near the extreme volatility of 2022 in any measure. My tracking chart of daily +/- 2% or larger moves in the S&P 500 below shows just how relatively small the volatility has been in the current chop this year. Currently the VIX volatility "fear gauge" has been trading in a relatively low channel, but that could change quickly and represents another important indicator.

While the weekly and monthly charts tend to show more extreme declines and the most stark perception of the 2022 pullback, the daily reality of the (SPY) declines four years ago looked like this. We had many intraday and daily signals through the long negative monthly signal.

Midterm Anomalies

The last comparison I will offer among many possibilities is that both 2022 and 2026 are midterm election years.

This large data table shows all the largest drawdowns in midterm years from 1926 to 2022, with an average max drawdown in these midterm years of -18.2% for the S&P 500. To date, the largest weekly drawdown is only -1.39%, and there have been many record highs for the S&P 500 since the start of the year.

Conclusion

Since we began testing these unique long-term portfolio models here on Seeking Alpha from the peer-reviewed financial literature, we have seen strong positive results exceeding market averages.

Over the years, I have found that timing matters greatly and buy/hold returns can be further enhanced.

Scholars have documented for years that "harvesting different risk baskets, each with a premium that has low-to-negative correlations to the others," is an excellent way to produce strong risk-adjusted returns. These ongoing sector rotations and signal changes continue to give us many new opportunities for profit in the years ahead as we build our optimal portfolio mixes each year.

I always encourage considering three steps in stock selection, whether for long-term value or short-term gains:

  1. Check the direction of the Market Gauges for the largest positive flows.
  2. Identify the Sector Gauges that are most positive and least extended to further enhance the probabilities of gains.
  3. Lastly, confirm the positive MDA breakout signals on individual stocks in the best sector and best market conditions to maximize returns.

I wish you well in all your trading decisions,

JD Henning, PhD.

data.title: The ETFs Powering The AI Supply Chain
data.description:
Artificial intelligence doesnâ€™t run on software alone. It depends on semiconductors, energy, and critical materials. Explore the ETFs providing exposure to the AI buildout.

What Actually Powers AI?

Itâ€™s easy to think of AI as a purely digital phenomenon built on code and data floating in the cloud. But every model runs on physical hardware, consumes real electricity, and depends on materials that are pulled from the ground.

Training a frontier model like GPT-4 reportedly consumed around 50 gigawatt-hours of energy, which is enough to power San Francisco for three days.1 And thatâ€™s just the training phase. Inference, which is the process of actually serving AI to hundreds of millions of users, demands even more sustained power over time.

All of that computation flows through three critical layers:

  • Semiconductors that do the math.
  • Energy that keeps the data centers running around the clock.
  • Strategic metals embedded in the hardware itself.

When any of those layers hits a bottleneck like a chip shortage, a power constraint, or an export ban on critical minerals, it affects every corner of the AI economy.

How Can You Invest in the AI Supply Chain?

Rather than chasing the handful of software names that dominate AI headlines, investors can target the physical infrastructure that every one of those companies depends on. VanEck offers three ETFs, each mapped to a distinct layer of the AI supply chain.

ETF Role in AI Supply Chain Why It Matters for AI Why Invest
SMH The advanced chips: GPUs, AI accelerators, that perform the trillions of calculations behind model training and inference. Hyperscalers are spending hundreds of billions on AI compute. No chips, no AI. Concentrated access to the 25 largest U.S.-listed semiconductor companies.
NLR Uranium mining, reactor construction, and nuclear power generation: the 24/7 baseload electricity AI requires. Data center power demand is set to double by 2030. Nuclear is the only scalable zero-carbon option. Full nuclear value chain exposure, from miners to utilities.
REMX Rare earth and strategic metals embedded in every server and data center. China controls ~90% of rare earth processing. Supply chain risk is real and growing. Pure-play global exposure to miners, refiners, and recyclers of critical metals.

Source: VanEck. These are not recommendations to buy or to sell any security.

How the AI Supply Chain Works

AI runs on physical infrastructure. Before a model can answer a question or generate an image, semiconductors have to process the data, power plants have to keep the servers running, and raw materials have to be mined, refined, and built into hardware. Each layer depends on the one below it. Hereâ€™s how the three layers connect.

Why Semiconductors Are Critical to AI?

Without advanced chips, none of this works. GPUs and custom accelerators handle the trillions of matrix multiplications required to train large language models, generate images, and run autonomous systems. The entire AI wave is, at its core, a semiconductor demand story.

The semiconductor industry also has a structural moat and only a handful of companies worldwide can manufacture the most advanced chips. That concentration creates real pricing power and long-duration demand for the companies at the top of the food chain.

SMH: Invest in the Semiconductors Driving AI

The VanEck Semiconductor ETF (SMH) tracks the MVISÂ® US Listed Semiconductor 25 Index, covering the largest U.S.-listed chip companies across design, manufacturing, and equipment. Itâ€™s a single way to access the core of the AI buildout.

Why AI Needs Reliable Energy

The challenge is that most of the U.S. energy grid was built decades ago. Solar and wind help, but theyâ€™re intermittent - and a data center canâ€™t afford to go dark when the wind stops blowing.

Thatâ€™s why nuclear is getting serious attention. Microsoft (MSFT), Meta (META), and Amazon (AMZN) have all announced plans to secure nuclear power for their AI infrastructure. The federal government has moved to ease nuclear plant regulations and fund next-generation reactor designs. Nuclear delivers exactly what a data center needs: reliable, scalable, zero-carbon baseload power, 24 hours a day.

NLR: Invest in the Industry Powering AI

The VanEck Uranium and Nuclear ETF (NLR) covers the full nuclear value chain - uranium mining, reactor construction and engineering, maintenance, and electricity generation. The fund tracks the MVISÂ® Global Uranium & Nuclear Energy Index. For investors looking to position for the nuclear renaissance that AI is accelerating, NLR offers a direct way in.

What Materials Are Important to AI?

Every AI chip, server rack, and cooling system is built from a cocktail of specialized metals. Here are a few raw materials that matter most:

  • Neodymium and dysprosium power the high-strength permanent magnets inside hard drives, server fans, and cooling pumps.
  • Copper carries massive electrical currents through the busbars and wiring that connect clustered AI systems.
  • Tantalum goes into the capacitors that regulate voltage in GPUs and memory modules during rapid workload shifts.
  • Gallium and germanium are essential for advanced chip fabrication and the high-speed fiber optics inside data centers.

The geopolitical dimension here is hard to ignore. China produces the majority of the worldâ€™s rare earths and controls nearly all of the processing capacity. The Chinese government recently imposed export licensing rules that require foreign buyers to disclose end-use applications - effectively restricting access for U.S. defense and advanced technology purchasers.

Western governments are investing in domestic mining and processing alternatives, but reshoring these supply chains is a multi-year project. Demand from the AI buildout, meanwhile, keeps climbing.

REMX: Invest in the Materials Building AI

The VanEck Rare Earth and Strategic Metals ETF (REMX) tracks the MVISÂ® Global Rare Earth/Strategic Metals Index, which requires constituent companies to derive at least 50% of revenue from the rare earth and strategic metals industry.

Invest in the AI Buildout with VanEck

The biggest AI winners over the next decade may not be the companies writing the models. They may be the companies making the chips those models run on, generating the electricity those chips consume, and mining the metals that make all the hardware possible.

VanEckâ€™s AI supply chain ETFs let investors gain targeted exposure to the physical infrastructure that every AI company depends on.
